If that is the genuine assessment of the companies concerned, no cash bid will be offered and the whole question disappears off the agenda. It slides into the swamp of irrelevancy.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of supplementary question, I ask: If it is a spurious argument, why did the Commonwealth Government agree to accede to a deferment of this for two years?

—It had never been the Commonwealth Government's intention while I was in that job-I understand the same policy was carried on by Senator Evans-that that particular part of the off-shore area would be put up for cash bids at this time.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to a Press report in yesterday's West Australian from the shadow Minister for Education, Senator Baume, entitled: 'Ryan in cover up'? In this report Senator Baume claims that the Minister is in breach of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act. He also alleges that the Minister for Education is hiding funding classifications of non-government schools. Since this is unlikely to be the case, I ask the Minister: What is the real situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I find it regrettable that Senator Baume is persisting in his useless and negative strategy of putting out statements based on absolute falsehood and deliberately attempting to mislead the education community about matters of Government policy. There may well be matters of legitimate or authentic debate between the Government and Opposition on matters of education policy. Unfortunately Senator Baume has decided to avoid those and simply spends his time running about trying to stir up mischief by deliberately misleading anyone who is gullible enough to take notice of what he has printed in the Press. The facts are quite contrary to what Senator Baume claims in his Press release. Not only are they contrary to his public claim; they are also well known to Senator Baume. I am aware of this because I am aware that Senator Baume sought from the Schools Commission advice about the timing of the gazettal of the new categories system for the funding of non-government schools and was given advice, based on legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department, to the effect that the Schools Commission and indeed the Government were conforming with the legal requirements with regard to the gazettal of schools.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that a period had elapsed since the announcement of the new scheme and the completion of the categorisation of individual schools into that scheme. However, I should point out that that time is not inconsiderable in comparison with the time that elapsed during the period of the Fraser Government. When Senator Baume was Minister for Education, for example, the list of schools categories was not available until November in the relevant year.

I believe that the publication of the categorisation of schools will be available very shortly because the list has been approved by me for gazettal. It was approved by me for gazettal last week and any time that elapses now between my approval and the gazettal will simply be a matter of the Government Printer getting the information into the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

All schools have been notified individually, with very few exceptions, those exceptions being due to some holdups in the provision of data. Of course, once schools are gazetted they are entitled to appeal if they believe they have grounds to go into a more favourable category. The vast bulk of schools have been notified of their categories for for some time. The list has been approved by me for gazettal and is with the Government Printer now. All of these steps are in accordance with legal requirements.

I conclude by saying that I think it is regrettable that Senator Baume chooses to act in such a deliberately misleading fashion, when there are no grounds for such behaviour, instead of paying attention to the real issues that confront educationalists in our society.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education: Did I make a freedom of information request to her earlier this year seeking the release of a list of schools to which she has just been referring? Was the request properly made? Did it require a response under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act? Is it a fact that no response has been given within the prescribed time? If so, why is that the case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was advised very recently by the Commonwealth Schools Commission of a request by Senator Baume under the Freedom of Information Act covering the matter of which schools get into which categories. I am now speaking from memory but, as I recall, I was also advised that the information cannot be released under the Freedom of Information Act until it has been gazetted. I understand that Senator Baume has been advised to that effect by the Schools Commission.
—Not so.

—Senator Baume says by way of interjection: 'Not so'. All that I can report to the Senate is that I was briefed on this matter by Schools Commission officers last week and I understand that, following legal advice that they have sought, they will be advising Senator Baume, if they have not yet done so, that the information he is seeking under the Freedom of Information Act needs to be in a gazetted form before he can have it.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that I am answering this specific matter from memory. If any further information is available or if it is necessary to qualify the information I have given I will do that as soon as possible. The fact is that the information being sought will be gazetted and there has been no undue delay caused by anything other than the capacity of the Commission to analyse carefully the data that has been presented to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to accept that I have received no formal notification of any kind from the Schools Commission on this matter. I therefore repeat my question to the Minister: Why was a proper response to a properly made freedom of information request not made by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, which is under her ministerial control, within the time provided in the Freedom of Information Act?

—I will have to seek further advice from the Commission. As I have just informed the Senate, I was advised of this matter by Commission officers last week. There was discussion about how Senator Baume's request could be accommodated and I understood that Senator Baume was to be informed by the Commission of the result of the legal advice sought by it. If there has been a delay in this matter I will have to seek an explanation from the Commission as to why that was the case, but I gained the impression from my discussions with Commission officers that they had been assiduously pursuing the matter of Senator Baume's inquiry and would be responding to it as soon as they were able to do so.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that single personnel at Australian Antarctic stations are charged the full Medicare levy while single personnel in the armed services pay none? Since both groups are entitled to free medical attention but Antarctic personnel have no access to specialist or hospital treatment, will the Minister consider action to remove this anomaly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the situation is that single personnel at the Australian Antarctic stations who are Australian residents are liable for the Medicare levy of 1 per cent but that Defence Force personnel who are overseas are exempt from the levy, as I believe they are also exempt when they are in Australia proper. In considering this matter it must be borne in mind that Medicare is not an insurance plan but rather a national health pool to which persons contribute according to their income. The overriding principle of the Medicare funding arrangements is that people are asked to pay in accordance with their means.

ANSWER.PARA: Exemption from payment of the levy is granted in limited circumstances to certain persons, including single Defence Force personnel. However, I remind Senator Zakharov that these limited exemptions reflect long-standing arrangements that have been adhered to by successive governments to provide free medical treatment to the persons concerned, that is, single defence personnel.

Granting an exemption from the levy to Australian Antarctic personnel would not be consistent with the Government's position that liability for the levy should be based on the person's capacity to pay. It would also create a precedent and other employees who are provided with free or subsidised medical care while still being subject to the Medicare levy would seek to have the concession extended to them, which would thereby further reduce the base of the levy.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Peter Rae proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Prime Minister and the Government to respond clearly and firmly to the depreciation of the Australian dollar.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is, I believe, rightly concerned, as has been indicated by the number of people who have shown their support of our discussion, by the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government to respond clearly and firmly to the depreciation of the Australian dollar. The Senate is concerned, as is the market concerned, and as the people of Australia and of the world are concerned, as has been indicated, by the very factors which have led to the currency crisis and the depreciation of the dollar. There has been a massive loss of confidence in this country, both within the country and overseas. One person primarily must accept the responsibility for that loss of confidence. That is the person who was recently to be heard explaining away his shuffling, his incoherence, his incapacity to come to grips with any of the problems which are causing the uncertainty in relation to the economy, that is, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

SPEECH.PARA: We have massive bad economic news. What do we find? We find that people have lost faith in thespianism as a substitute for government decision-making. We find that summitry has become the suspicious substitute for the capacity to take hard decisions. We find that the left wing of the Australian Labor Party has been attacking again in relation to the Prime Minister's tax agenda and almost all of the matters which the Prime Minister wishes to have as part of the policies applying to the Government of this country. If we look at the policies enunciated by the Prime Minister during the last election and then explained by him on the National when he was interviewed by Mr Maximilian Walsh, it is easy for us to see where all the problems in this country stem from. We find that interest rates are blowing out at an extraordinary rate. We find an admission that Reserve Bank activity has been taking place in forcing up interest rates. We find that our competitiveness, the lack of which has been the cause of our suffering so badly, which could be overcome by the devaluation, whatever the cause of the devaluation may have been, is at risk as things stand.

My colleague Senator Messner in particular will be dealing with some of the reasons why we feel so concerned about the lack of Government positiveness and direction in relation to what it is going to do to enable this country to take advantage of the opportunities which arise out of the devaluation and to avoid the pitfalls which may beset us. I wish to refer to an editorial which appeared in the Melbourne Age of Monday, 15 April. I do not intend to quote the whole detail of the editorial although it could form the basis of a speech such as the one I am making. The editorial stated.:
However, business remains cautious. Capital investment rises, but modestly.
I pause there to say: Very modestly in all the circumstances. If one takes the inflation impact into account, the increased rises are extremely modest and tentative. The editorial continued:

Spending by consumers is still erratic and much leaks overseas, benefiting foreign producers. Manufacturers, after a decade of rising costs, is still on the ropes, unable to compete in the international marketplace. There can be no certainty that the private sector will take over from the public sector 'kick-start'. Some spark is needed to inject confidence into the business community and provide real incentives in the marketplace.
The editorial referred to the fact that since Christmas devaluation has been close to 20 per cent overall. It continued:

The opportunity is to seize the benefits of the devaluation to shake off once and for all the sluggish economic performance that has bedevilled the nation . . . The devaluation could not have been better timed if it had been planned, instead of being the by-product of a series of policy blunders.
A little later the editorial stated:

And it is exactly that spark which could make such a sustained upturn a reality. Yet, rather than enthusiasm, the falling dollar has in the main sparked fear and gloom. Why? The answer is a widespread expectation that we will let pass the opportunity and fail the challenge. The reason for this view is the accord . . .
I just wish to re-emphasise those words. They are not my words; they are the words of the Editor of the Age who has not been unsympathetic to this Government. The editorial stated:
Yet, rather than enthusiasm, the falling dollar has in the main sparked fear and gloom. Why? The answer is a widespread expectation that we will let pass the opportunity and fail the challenge.
A little later the editorial stated:
It is not the time for equivocation. The Prime Minister's performance last week was hardly encouraging as he dithered, increasingly verbosely, around the devaluation/ wage issue.
The editorial also said:
Very simply, Australia has been living beyond its means, relying on the rest of the world to subsidise our endemic trade deficits.

What is this Government doing about the matters which are referred to in the editorial? What is the situation? We find just a series of bad economic news. Retail sales to February continued the steep decline of January. Normally, the decline in January is very steep indeed but it levels out or even starts to pick up again in February. But that was not the case this February. This February the decline continued almost as fast and almost as steeply as the January decline, unlike what happened in 1983 and 1984. That is a matter of very real concern. Many people who have analysed the sales figures believe that the figures for January and a significant part of those for February have in fact been related to devaluation. People have been trying to beat the import price rise by purchasing goods which otherwise are likely to be affected as devaluation starts to bite into the economic community and the price of goods rises.

We have a currency crisis in which there has been a 20 per cent devaluation in three months. That devaluation has been the product of the international judgment not of the economic future of Australia but of the economic management of Australia. I believe that this point is of the utmost importance. It is one that this Government cannot escape. The fact is that there is a widespread belief within this country and elsewhere that Australia remains a country of great hope and great expectation as to its future. It is a country which, if it can overcome some of its fundamental problems, has prospects rivalled by almost no other country. It is positioned in an area which will see major growth and development in the next decade and to the end of the century. It is positioned in an area where it can take advantage. It has the capacity, the systems, the training, the people and the infrastructure which would enable it to play a major part in the major growth area of the world. What is preventing that from happening? Why is it that people have made the judgment which they have made since we floated the dollar? After all, when we floated the dollar Australia was subjected to the judgment of the international market-place. That judgment is that our continuing trade current account deficit, our continuing problems in industrial matters, our continuing bad record in relation to the delivery of goods and our continuing bad administration and lack of faith and direction in this Government are matters of sufficient concern for people to believe that the Australian dollar is not worth what otherwise I believe people would rate it at.

Contrary to all of the promises which we were made by Mr Keating and Mr Hawke during the election campaign last year, we find that there has been a huge growth in interest rates. We find that we now have the highest interest rates that this country has known since the Great Depression at the beginning of the 1930s. This is notwithstanding what Mr Keating said in the period running up to the election last year. The Australian Labor Party and Mr Keating appeared to be very proud that he had done such a magnificent job. On 4 November last year he said:

. . . I'm sure that if, as we get through the tax run-down period of this year, where the market's always a little apprehensive now after the float, of about the capacity of funding the tax run-down period, you'll see declines in interest rates.
But have we seen any indication of declines in interest rates? On 5 November last year Mr Hawke said:
. . . because inflation is coming down and inflationary expectations are down interest rates will come down too.

Despite that, what we see now is an interest rate of 17 per cent and a real interest rate of 12 per cent. This is the highest real interest rate that this country has known since the Great Depression. It is one of the highest real interest rates operating in the world today.

What do we find in relation to our public debt? We find that that public debt is rising at an incredibly fast rate because action is not being taken to redress the balance of trade, to encourage exports which could be encouraged by a positive and enthusiastic approach to the administration of industry and commerce policy, technology policy and trade policy. Instead, we have seen the tentativeness and desperateness of the factionalism which has rent the Labor Party and the Government into so many parts. So many people have no faith whatever in the capacity of the Prime Minister or anybody else to speak on behalf of the Government. People have no belief that whatever is said will still be said next week. Then we have the trade deficit. Huge borrowings are needed to keep up the balance of trade. Of course, the flow-on effect of the cost of high borrowings overseas makes greater the cost of the devaluation of Australia. It seems that early today, in answer to a question, Senator Walsh was not so clear in his thinking about this as he might be now that he has had a little bit more time to consider it. I ask him again whether he will answer the question a little more clearly. It seems to me that we have a situation in which the Government has adopted a very different approach. Mr Hawke in Perth last Friday referred to an expected windfall. He said:
With the depreciation of the dollar and prospects for a stronger growth in employment than previously anticipated, the Government will be seeking to achieve maximum reductions in outlays in 1985-86.
A little later he said:

The depreciation may have the immediate effect of increasing revenue more than it raises the cost of maintaining priority. None of this increase in net revenue, if it occurs, will be used to increase government outlays. The Government will decide on the most effective means of achieving this result when the full extent of the post-depreciation improvement in the budgetary outlook is known.
The result to which he was referring was given when he said:

The whole of any increased budgetary flexibility following the depreciation will be applied to strengthening the economy's prospects for even stronger private sector growth in output and employment with low inflation.

I remind the Senate that last August the Budget was introduced in an atmosphere in which there was likely to be an early election. All the benefits that had come from the wage pause, the breaking of the drought and the upturn in the world economy were frittered away, were spent by this Government, were used in outlays, were used to buy the appearance of an upturn in employment, were used to buy the appearance of an upturn in the economy, were used not for investment in the future of the nation, not for the reduction of debt but for the postponement of debt and, in fact, the increase in debt which accompanied the high spending, high taxing policy which was adopted by the Government in the Budget of last August.

Now we find Senator Walsh this afternoon saying and Mr Hawke last Friday saying: 'Now we will adopt an entirely different approach'. What I would like Senator Walsh to answer is what is so different now from then in that sort of policy decision making. Is it that last year there was a faith in the prices and incomes accord which does not exist now, or is it that last year there was just a deliberate buying of votes by putting forth an election Budget knowing that it would have repercussions which may even lead to the need for or the creation of a situation of devaluation, with a floating currency? That would lead to a situation in which it was necessary to prop up the capital inflow of Australia by artificially propping up interest rates. That admission of the artificial propping up of interest rates is one which I believe Australians need to be told over and over again. Do not let us have any of this business that the Government is not really responsible for the interest rates which home owners and borrowers will have to pay, which will have an inflationary impact as the costs flow through to business as well as to individuals. Mr Hawke, in his interview on 10 April 1985, confirmed that it was the action of the Government which had led to the increase in interest rates. I read from page 2 of the transcript of that interview. Mr Maximilian Walsh said:
And in fact interest rates have moved up in Australia quite severely and substantially of late.
The Prime Minister said:
There has been a move upwards, yes.
Mr Walsh said:
Which one would infer came from Reserve Bank action in the market place.
The Prime Minister said:
There has obviously been a degree of action there in the market place, yes.

He was agreeing that it was Government action which was pushing up interest rates. There are other quotes to which I do not intend to pay attention. So what do we find? We find we have a situation of complete confusion about the question of wages and devaluation. On 26 February this year the Prime Minister said that no action would be taken on discounting and the priority was to maintain the accord, but Senator Walsh said that there would be little effect on the consumer price index. It was reported on 26 February that wages would be discounted. So we go on with all of these confusing statements which my colleagues will deal with in detail as we go through, showing that there is not only confusion about that sort of approach but also about what sort of policy will be adopted in relation to expenditure cuts. The tertiary fees proposal by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, was rejected by Caucus. There are reports that Senator Walsh was defeated and that Cabinet's razor gang committee was defeated by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy. It is alleged that there will be a substantial increase-in fact, an 18 per cent increase-in the amount of money going to the ABC in the next year. By anybody's terms, that would be a significant increase. It hardly supports the idea of the trilogy. It hardly supports the idea of a cautious government taking every possible action to curtail expenditure.

As we look through some of the other steps that have been taken we find that in the last few weeks alone there has been bad economic news on almost every count. The Australian dollar, interest rates, unemployment figures, the current account deficit and the latest retail sales figures all amount to trouble for this Government which it does not appear to be acknowledging is in existence. If it acknowledged that there was a problem and if it had a clear policy as to how it will get out of it one could have some faith, but the trilogy is more than what Mr Maximilian Walsh reminded us was the Oxford English Dictionary definition of the work 'trilogy'-a set of three tragedies to be performed in immediate succession. Is that what we are facing? Is that what the figures which we are now seeing, created by the actions of this Government, amount to? Is it not a situation in which this country deserves better, in which this country deserves that the Prime Minister and the Government should respond clearly and firmly to the depreciation of the Australian dollar, make clear what their policies will be, make clear what policy actions are to be taken to ensure that there is a restoration of national and international confidence in the country and, from that, growth of the sorts of opportunities which we all believe and hope will come to fruition for this country? This country has a tremendous future which is being frittered away by the thespianism and dilatoriness of the dilettantish Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae demanded to know right at the end of his speech what policy is being followed by the Government in regard to the exchange rate. I thought that it had been made perfectly clear to anybody who wanted to listen that in response over a number of weeks to assorted informed or ill-informed demands that the Government should intervene and end the floating of the Australian dollar the Government said it will not do that. The Government has said that the decision was taken 18 months ago to float the Australian dollar and that decision stands. Having made that decision it would, of course, be absurd for a government to intervene in the way that governments which are trying to manage an exchange rate do intervene. Indeed, it would be to take us right back to the position which applied immediately before the 1983 election when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), as he now is, as a Minister in the then Government, as he then was, put on his economic saboteur or economic quisling act and a week or a fortnight before the election was held said that if Labor was elected there would be a severe devaluation of the Australian dollar, thereby precipitating a run on the dollar which ultimately fleeced hundreds of millions off the Australian taxpayers via the Reserve Bank's attempts to resist the run on the dollar which the irresponsible comments by the present Leader of the Opposition had started. Consciously or otherwise, the present Leader of the Opposition collaborated at that time with the overseas currency raiders who filched hundreds of millions off the taxpayers of Australia via the Reserve Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one issue, it is true, on which the Government has not yet stated a firm policy, because it has many options under consideration. That issue is whether the Government will argue before the relevant national wage case, which will not take place until the spring of this year, that there should be a complete or a partial discounting of the devaluation induced consumer price index changes when assessing the change that ought to be made at the next national wage case. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made it perfectly clear on many occasions that that is a matter which will not become directly relevant for several months and it is, therefore, a matter upon which this Government will not be stampeded into a hasty or foolish decision.

I must correct the retail sales statistics which Senator Rae mentioned twice and which, therefore, he obviously regards as being particularly important. The statements he made were correct if based on figures which were not seasonally adjusted but, as I am sure Senator Rae would know, when making comparisons over short periods such as that and especially at that time of the year, seasonally adjusted figures are the more appropriate ones to use. Even on a seasonally adjusted basis it is correct that there was a minuscule decline in retail sales in February compared with the January figure. The February figure, however, is higher than the December figure and, indeed, it is the second highest figure since December 1983; that is, it is only lower than the previous January figure. The February figure is the second highest figure since December 1983 and probably, I would expect, the second highest monthly figure ever recorded. But I cannot state that with certainty because the chart I have does not go back beyond December 1983. I repeat: It is certainly the second highest figure since December 1983 and probably the second highest figure ever recorded.

That hardly supports the gloom and doom hypothesis just advanced by Senator Rae. Indeed, one cannot help wondering about Senator Rae when he makes that comment and, I would suggest, misrepresentation: Perhaps one should say 'misunderstanding' because 'misrepresentation' implies a deliberate intent and I do not know whether that was present. When the gloom and doom, supported by a misunderstanding of the retail sales figures, is put alongside the other gloom and doom messages in Senator Rae's speech one cannot help wondering whether he too has succumbed to the temptation to become an economic saboteur, an economic quisling, in the way his Leader did in the runup to the 1983 election.

In determining the proper response to the price changes induced by the changing value of the Australian dollar, the Government certainly cannot look to the Opposition for any guidance. Probably the most important single consumer price index factor is the price of oil and its relationship to the Australian-United States dollar exchange rate. I remind the Senate that Mr Hunt, the Deputy Leader of the National Party these days, stated immediately after the 1983 election that he would be standing down from the front bench because he believed that it was time to make way for a younger and more active member. I do not think that was seriously disputed. He said that he would be standing down. Subsequently, Mr Anthony, the then Leader of the National Party, retired. Mr Hunt, who only one month before had declared himself to be a political corpse, was then resurrected as the Deputy Leader of the National Party. That says something about the bevy of talent that was offering, but, more importantly, it meant that we had leading the National Party both the undertaker and the corpse. (Quorum formed)

Senator Sheil called a quorum because he wanted more people to hear what I was saying immediately beforehand, so I will oblige him and repeat it. I was explaining how the present Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Hunt, immediately following the 1983 election, had declared that it was time for him to stand down from the front bench and make way for a more vigorous, more intelligent or more youthful politician-a proposition with which there was no serious argument. However, following the retirement of his then Leader, Mr Anthony, Mr Hunt, who had declared himself to be a political corpse, resurrected himself as Deputy Leader of the National Party. As a result of that action we now have leading the National Party both the undertaker and the corpse. I refer to Mr Hunt because of the statement he made on 12 April-just last week-in respect of the import parity pricing policy for Australian crude oil. He said:
Action must be taken to ensure that not only farmers but motorists generally are not ripped off by a policy that was devised in entirely different circumstances of fuel shortages in the mid 1970's.
He added:
Clearly, there is a need for an urgent review of the existing policy in the light of changed circumstances.
Two days later the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and leader of the Sydney faction of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard, said:
One of the options apparently being looked at by the Government is temporary suspension of import parity pricing for Australian crude oil.
Mr Howard added:
Such action to mitigate the price effects of depreciation is illogical, economically irrational and should not be taken up.

That could lead to all sorts of interesting speculation: Should the Liberal Party ever return to a position of government in coalition, when it will still carry in its saddle-bags the lead of the National Party, will it have the fortitude to throw off its neck what the Australian Financial Review called the 'stinking albatross' of the National Party or will it in future continue to do what it has done in the past-will it follow a rational policy or capitulate to the political opportunists and economic primitives who have always dominated that Party? Apart from the internal conflicts over policy within the Liberal Party there is this much more profound conflict between the Liberal Party and the National Party, exemplified very clearly in starkly and completely contradictory terms by the respective deputy leaders only last week. If the Government felt that it needed to look outside the Government for guidance it certainly could not expect to find any guidance from the Opposition, or at least any guidance that was worth listening to.

I think the partial explanation for the Opposition deciding to propose this matter of public importance is pique. The Opposition is piqued-I can understand this; we are all human-that this Government has such a hugely impressive economic record. (Quorum formed) I was saying-much to the pain of the Opposition, apparently, because it decided to stop me saying it-that this Government has had a most impressive record in economic growth and economic management in general during the time that it has been in office. An extra opportunity has been given-or extra potential, if one likes-because of the devaluation of the dollar. The prospect of economic growth has been enhanced further by the recent downward adjustments in the value of the dollar, a point which the Prime Minister made last week and which the Opposition has quoted ad infinitum ever since. The devaluation has substantially improved Australia's competitiveness not only in regard to exporting industries but also import competing industries.

A major challenge for the Government and for the community in general is to ensure that the competitive edge given us by that devaluation is not lost through higher labour costs. The Government has worked hard to get the inflation rate down and is determined to keep it down. It is imperative that enhanced competitiveness is not cancelled by rising labour costs. Unemployment remains at intolerably high levels. This devaluation-induced opportunity to boost employment must not be missed by raising the incomes of the employed at the expense of the jobless. The prevention of a flow-on will require co-operative effort. I say to Senator Messner that I have already made the point during Question Time that the previous Government, in which he was a Minister in its dying days-I am not sure what is cause and what is effect in that regard-argued in the mid to late 1970s that devaluation-induced price increases should not be taken into account in national wage cases. That argument was substantially accepted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on at least one occasion. But the plain fact is that that did not keep inflation down. At the end of the road of the previous Government's policy we had the highest rate of unemployment that we had had since the 1930s, the highest interest rates ever, inflation and unemployment rates in double figures-and they were both rising-and an absolute fall in gross domestic product in the last 12 months in which it was effectively in control of economic policy.

The point is that it would be relatively easy for the Liberal Party-and I suppose if it were still in government this is what it would do-to rush to the Arbitration Commission and say: 'You have to discount the devaluation-induced CPI effects when you consider the next national wage case', and take no other actions or put together no policy package that would ensure that such a policy had a chance of attaining its actual objectives. This Government will not be stampeded into that sort of precipitate action which may ultimately reduce the chances of a successful policy actually being applied.

Finally, I was somewhat impressed by Senator Peter Rae's remarks about fiscal responsibility and, in particular, responsibility in expenditure control. I should note in all fairness that Senator Rae was never a Minister in the last Liberal Government. There were a number of reasons for that, about which I will not speculate. But it is a fact that he was never a Minister in that Government. But Senator Messner, who will speak shortly, was a Minister in that Government. If he wants to go further down the road of fiscal rectitude, responsibility and expenditure, I hope he will give us an explanation as to why the Government in which he was a Minister produced in its dying months a Budget which left the country with a prospective deficit of nearly $10 billion, and which had absolutely no economic strategy. His Government had only a political strategy aimed entirely at being re-elected by handing out with reckless abandon bribes by way of either tax concessions or direct Government outlays to what it judged to be a sufficient number of pressure groups to buy up enough votes to save its worthless hide for another term in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, one of the most worthless speeches that I have ever heard in regard to any economic matter or, from my point of view, any other matter. He not only fell short in any attempt to answer the major criticisms that were made by Senator Peter Rae during his excellent speech on this matter of public importance, but also, of course, failed even to try to cover up for his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is now floundering at the head of this failing Government as it falls deeper and deeper into the mire. The kind of remarks which Senator Walsh has made today will only confirm the perceptions of those overseas who are judging this country's economic performance today by making sure that the Australian dollar falls even further. It is this kind of lack of management and lack of control of the economy and of Australian affairs both on world markets and domestically that are leading to the disasters that this Government is failing to recognise.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with one or two points that Senator Walsh made. He sought to take Senator Rae to task over the question of falling retail sales in the month of February. We know full well from the statistics issued today that retail sales have fallen in seasonally adjusted terms by a most significant figure of 1.2 per cent. That is a most significant drop. But the point that Senator Rae made, which is the more important one, is that the fall in unadjusted terms, compared with the figures for January, is the greatest that has occurred for the last three years. Does that not say something about a change of face in this country? What is this Government doing about it? I was about to say that there was not even a Minister in the chamber but the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, has now entered the chamber.

What is this Government doing about those vital questions? A week or so ago there was an announcement of an increase in unemployment of 30,000. Unemployment normally falls at this time of the year as school leavers are taken into industry and consequently the number who register for unemployment benefits during the December-January period starts to fall. Yet this Government shows no concern about the unemployed and no concern about the fall in retail sales. It says: 'That is nothing to do with us. We will not take any action to support the Australian dollar'.

Let us try to work out what is really happening in this country. The basic issue that is at stake at present is Australia's competitive position on world markets. We on this side of the House know what that means. We know after seven years in government how hard it is to get the inflation rate down to a significant figure. We know how much of a trial has to be gone through in order to reduce our costs in this country to a level at which we can sell goods on overseas markets and, more importantly, produce goods in this country which can be sold on the domestic market and which will not be competed against by cheaper goods from overseas.

Let me refer to a few statistics that result from the action of governments. First of all we have to acknowledge-the figures were announced yesterday-that there is an $11 billion prospective deficit on our balance of payments for this financial year, for the year ending 30 June 1985. That is the highest deficit that this country has ever experienced. Let us look at the inflow of foreign investment moneys as revealed recently. The inflow for the 12 months to the year ended December 1984 was some $7.8 billion. That figure falls a lot short of the $9 billion that was recorded in 1983. It is also acknowledged by those in the market-place that most of the money that is now arriving as part of capital inflow is not permanent investment money and that is reflected in the lower fixed capital investment figures; it obviously comes into Australia in response to short term interest rate fluctuations and fluctuations in the value of the dollar. I also note that even the low capital inflow figure of $7.8 billion for this year has been influenced by a large capital inflow from semi-government authorities that have been borrowing. I bet they regret that they borrowed in the period to December as the currency has now suffered a 20 per cent devaluation. Consequently higher interest rates will obviously flow through to those organisations. The same situation will apply to all organisations that have borrowed on the world markets. They will now have to recoup sufficiently from consumers-whether they be ratepayers or those who use electricity-in order to be able to pay off debts in the future. That is one of the fundamental problems that this country will face in the years ahead. Of course it exacerbates our problems with costs.

Let us look at interest rates. Before Christmas, during the election campaign, the Prime Minister prophesied-I guess the prophecy is as reliable as his ability to control the various factions in the Australian Labor Party:
Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the past 20 months.
I guess that he was talking about lenders, not borrowers. He stated:
We've ploughed the fields and sown the seeds. In the very near future we will harvest the crop.
We know who will harvest the crop; it will be the lenders and certainly not the borrowers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Great prophet!

—Exactly. A point we also have to acknowledge is that quite apart from nominal interest rates which we know are on the rise and which have been induced by direct government intervention by the Reserve Bank of Australia, real interest rates in this country-that is, nominal interest rates after adjusting for inflation-have risen by 500 per cent since this Government came to power in March 1983. At that stage, when the Fraser Government went out of power, real interest rates were one per cent; they are now 6.5 per cent. That is a massive increase and it is the highest real interest rate that has been suffered by taxpayers in this country for over 50 years. That is the real test of what is happening in the market-place. Overseas investors, overseas operators, even those domestically who are concerned about the future of the Australian dollar, have regarded these things even if the Australian Government has not.

SPEECH.PARA: The public debt situation is also causing great concern. Our repayments now represent $5.6 billion of the Australian Government's Budget and that represents an increase of 29 per cent on the 1983-84 figure and 8.7 per cent of all government spending. The public debt is rising and obviously is a major factor about which we should be concerned.

Let us look at the problems of import costs which have been rising. In the December 1983 quarter there was a fall in import cost of 1.6 per cent; in the latest quarter there was an increase of 4.6 per cent. Obviously this Government's policies are not working. Clearly these import rises are going to feed their way into the wages system. This is the fundamental point which has to be acknowledged and which this Government fails to acknowledge. Under the Government's present wages accord the increased costs, which are flowing in the fashion that I have just outlined and which will continue to flow and grow, stem directly from this Government's failure to address the mechanics of its wages system by which those increased amounts can be excluded from wages. Otherwise we will have a leap-frogging approach whereby costs feed into wages; wages, through the arbitration system, feed back into costs; and they in turn feed back into the wage system. Thus we will have the great leap-frogging situation which we had in the 1970s and which we found so very difficult to get of. It was brought to final account by the Fraser Government's wage pause during 1982 when no wage increases occurred for some eight or nine months.

It is that kind of question that this Government has to address. It has to examine its own soul. We know the political difficulties of doing that not only within the Party-the faction ridden Party that it is-but also within the trade union movement. That is the Government's natural constituency and it knows that it has to deal with the union movement in order to find a way of reducing the flow-on of wages, to protect this country against rising costs and future inflation. But will the Government do it? Has it got the political will to do it? To date the answer, of course, is that the Government does not. Clearly, that is the nub of this argument which we are putting forward today. I commend my colleague Senator Rae for bringing forward this matter of public importance today. It draws attention to the drift of the economy in this country which stems directly from this Government's inability to grasp the realities of the market-place and to move to adjust the flow of costs in this country which will permanently damage the economy in the future.

If we want any example of the paralysis of the Prime Minister let us think about who promoted the wage increases of the 1970s and, in particular, the 40 per cent wage increase that occurred in 1974. Who was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions? It was none other than Mr R. J. Hawke, the present Prime Minister of Australia. He is not interested in reducing wages or keeping them under control; he is interested in increasing them and that is where his political problem lies. He knows that his political power stems from appeasing the trade union movement, not from challenging it on the very issues which this nation has to confront in order to assure itself of a safe, economic future. That is a problem that we on this side of the chamber believe that this Government will fail to address. Otherwise we will see an increasing external debt which already reads out at $43.5 billion. I cite the figures as a proportion of gross domestic product. In 1970 our gross external debt was 12 per cent; in 1975 it was 9 1/2 per cent; in 1980 it was 12 1/2 per cent, but in 1984 it was 23 1/2 per cent. That figure will rise every year that this Government remains in power because of its big spending and obvious high deficit policies.

The Government has to come to terms with the introduction of its much touted floating of the Australian dollar and has to design mechanisms which if it has the political will-the Opposition doubts that it has-it will use to try to control the flow-on that will so damage the Australian economy. The test of what Mr Hawke can do to lead this country is before him right now. Can he do it? That remains to be seen, but an awful lot of people who are selling the dollar down do not believe that it is possible. One has only to read this fantastic transcript of the commentary of the Prime Minister and Max Walsh the other night-it was a thorough rambling through many irrelevant economic issues-to understand what fear the Prime Minister is striking in the hearts of Australians and people overseas about this lack of control and his lack of competence in managing this economy and to understand the point I am making.

I instance one final comment by the Prime Minister to demonstrate the point clearly. He claimed that the most recent devaluation of the dollar will create at least 100,000 jobs for Australians. If that be true, he has found the key to the solution of all our economic and unemployment problems. Australia has 600,000 unemployed people and the Prime Minister can get rid of that unemployment by devaluing the dollar to nil. Why does he not try to do that? Perhaps that is his strategy. Perhaps that is why he is raving like a lunatic about his so-called economic strategy. Perhaps that is what he has in mind. Clearly that is the idiocy of the Prime Minister's position and he stands condemned, alongside his Ministers, for failing to take action at this vital time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to this matter of public importance raised this afternoon by Senator Peter Rae, it is true that in recent weeks the value of the Australian dollar has gone down. However, it is arguable, as a number of commentators have said, that the dollar was overvalued. It had a higher value than it should have had in relation to Australia's fundamental trading relationships. The argument advanced by Senator Peter Rae assumes that the lower movement of the dollar will somehow be a medium to long term arrangement and that the dollar will stay down at those levels for a long time. But it is by no means clear that the dollar will stay down for any length of time at that value. I wonder how the Opposition will feel if in the near future the value of the dollar moves up again. What sorts of measures will Opposition members then call for in those circumstances? Will they be like some of the employer groups last year-when the Australian dollar rose-and call for discounting of the price effects of that revaluation of the dollar? If so, that will be the reverse of what is happening at present. It does not square up with the Opposition's arguments in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's record on the economy and the exchange rate is poor. Opposition members have tried to talk down the economy since they took over the Opposition benches in 1983, and yet over that period the economy has grown and grown. Let us look at the record of the Opposition on the exchange rate and recall what happened in 1972 under the McMahon Government. Then it was clear that the Australian dollar was undervalued-the reverse of the present position. The dollar should have been revalued on world markets, but that Government did nothing. For months the Australian dollar was consistently undervalued. As a result all kinds of distortions were engendered in the economy and economic costs were imposed on the Australian community. The Labor Party had to step into office and put the exchange rate to an appropriate value by means of a revaluation. The present Labor Government has floated the Australian dollar on currency markets-something the former Government would not do. At present, market forces are operating in Australian currency markets, but for some reason in this instance the Opposition does not like to see market forces in effect.

One of the key reasons for the recent devaluation has been the surge in imports, the leakage to overseas suppliers resulting from increased demand in the Australian economy. That is a well-known effect and occurs frequently in open trading economies such as Australia's economy. Between 10 and 20 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product is in traded goods, imports and exports, and it is evident that in such economies the level of imports is determined importantly by the level of activity and growth in the economy. Price levels-price competitiveness-are only one factor in determining levels of imports. Unfortunately, it seems that the Opposition has a fixation about cost levels and price competitiveness and is not prepared to look at the other forces at work in the economy-forces which, in the short to medium term, can affect levels of imports. That is a very important factor to bear in mind.

It is on record that in the 1983-84 financial year Australia experienced 10 per cent real growth through the year. From June 1983 to June 1984 Australia enjoyed 10 per cent real economic growth-the fastest growth in the world. That achievement has been ignored by the Opposition. Good growth is expected in the current financial year and it is now expected that the growth forecast in the Budget will be exceeded. In two financial years Australia has had strong economic growth. I believe that factor primarily has led to the surge in imports. As economic activity has picked up, there has been an increase in the imports of raw materials and capital equipment. The trend in Australia is fairly well documented for other industrialised economies which have experienced rapid economic growth.

It should be noted that the surge in imports is now slowing down. For example, the Melbourne Sun this morning points out that the growth in imports in the 12 months to March this year was lower than the growth in imports in the 12 months to December last year. That points to a downturn in the growth trend in imports. They are heartening figures. It is also important to note that the slowdown had begun to occur before the downward movement in the Australian dollar. The balance of payments figures which were released yesterday also help to expose one of the other economic arguments used by the Opposition as having no foundation. I have been a member of this place for almost two years and have repeatedly heard Opposition members point to the fact that the recovery in the Australian economy has been due to an upturn in the world economy. However, export prices received by Australian producers are not at high levels. It is most unlikely to expect export prices to be at low levels when there is a strong demand for one's products on world markets. If there is any effect flowing from the upturn in the world economy in terms of the Australian economy, I think a large part of it is yet to come and has not been built into production growth in this country to date.

It is also important to note that in regard to the balance of payments figures that were released yesterday there has now been, after seasonal adjustment, a balance of trade surplus-that is, an excess of exports over imports-for two consecutive months. That is a most important movement. I must concede, however, a problem in the balance of payments. It is not so much a problem in the balance of trade area, but in the capital movement area and also in regard to invisibles. Those invisible items in the balance of payments include such items as payments for shipping to overseas companies, insurance services, property income and so forth. There is a real problem in that area since Australia is now facing an invisibles deficit of some $5,000m to $6,000m each year. That large figure is a direct result of the policies pursued by the Menzies Government through the 1950s and 1960s-policies which progressively allowed, if I may put it metaphorically, the farm to be sold off and allowed increased overseas penetration of the Australian economy. Now a large part of our export bill each year effectively has to go to cover the costs to the Australian economy of a very large deficit on invisible items. That will take many years to rectify. I applaud the actions of the former Minister for Trade, Mr Lionel Bowen, in upgrading the machinery in the Department of Trade to deal with the invisibles deficit.

When one boils down the substance of this matter of public importance, it is seeking to deal with the potential inflationary effects of devaluation of the Australian economy. But it should be noted that any price effects, if they exist, will take time to feed through into the economy. They will be very small effects on the next wage indexation rise to be awarded in September or October. The fact is that that rise will be paid in relation to the two preceding quarters. Any price effects in the period of devaluation will be minimal. Whatever happens on this front will happen at some time in the future.

Honourable senators opposite cannot lecture us on inflation after their record in office. For seven years the Australian people were asked to bear sacrifices in the name of fighting inflation first. That was the policy of the Liberal-National Party Government-fighting inflation first. Yet when we assumed office at the beginning of 1983, inflation in this country was at double digit levels; it was 11.5 per cent. The Australian people had absolutely no return for all the sacrifices which they made for seven years in the name of fighting inflation first. Through the prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions we have developed a core policy which enables economic expansion to occur with lower inflationary consequences. Our record speaks for itself in the inflation area. We have more than halved the rate, from 11.5 per cent inherited by this Government, to just over 5 per cent on the latest available information for the year to the December quarter 1984. It is the lowest inflation rate we have had for years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the highest interest rate we have had since the Depression.

—How would Senator Peter Rae propose to deal with the high interest rate? I suppose he would raise inflation. We have had a very big reduction in inflation. One of the key differences between the Government and the Opposition parties is that the Government supports centralised wage fixing machinery. The Opposition has a different policy. Centralised wage fixing machinery gives much more scope to control any inflationary effects which might be engendered through external sources. Certainly, the centralised wage fixing system has more potential to stop price and cost explosions in the pressure sectors of the economy. We still need to know what is the Opposition's policy on wages. What is the Opposition's policy on incomes?
—You are in government. What is your policy on what is happening at the moment with the depreciation in the value of the dollar?

—Senator Peter Rae is in the Opposition. He brought up this matter today. I need to know what is the Opposition's policy on wages. On the one hand we have the Howard-Shack dry faction which wants to move away from centralised wage fixing to decentralised wage fixing with sector bargaining. Then we have the Macphee faction which supports centralised wage fixing. So it is not quite clear what the Opposition would do were it occupying the treasury bench and having to deal with the sorts of problems it is claiming this afternoon exist. Frankly, it does not have a wages policy which would offer any scope to do anything about cost pressures brought into the Australian economy from outside. We need only to look at its record in the 1981-82 period of the Fraser Government when Mr Howard was Treasurer. A partially decentralised wage fixing system developed at the time of the so-called resources boom. Fluctuations in the dollar and very rapid wage rises linked with the currency movements occurred. It was clear that the decentralised wage fixing system that the Liberal and National parties allowed to develop could not shield domestic costs from currency movements. That is the record of the early 1980s. There are big advantages, I believe, in having a centralised wage fixing policy such as that of the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important to bear in mind that a devaluation of the currency is not an unmitigated disaster. It has important potential economic effects on real economic activity. Devaluation should help expand domestic economic activity. As the cost of imports rises more effective protection is available, particularly for manufacturing industry and the import competing industries of our economy. Those which produce traded goods are given more protection from imports. There should be increases in the volume of production in those areas. It is possible that we will obtain more manufacturing exports as a result of the devaluation of the dollar. Our export industries whose prices are set in foreign currencies will do better because they will get bigger returns. Devaluation is not an economic disaster as some honourable senators on the Opposition benches would have us believe.

The fundamentals of the Australian economy today remain strong. In the key consumption spending and investment spending sections of the economy activity is running at above the levels forecast in the 1984-85 Budget. In both the public and private sectors 341,000 jobs have been created in this country since the present Government came into office. That is more jobs than were created in the whole period of the Liberal-National Party Government from 1975 to 1983. It is very important when the Opposition proposes matters for discussion in this chamber on devaluation and controlling its effects that it makes it clear to the people of Australia what its policies are on wages and whether it supports a centralised or decentralised wage fixing system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in joining Senator Peter Rae and Senator Messner in this debate. Before making the remarks I have in mind to make I will address a couple of the points that have been made by earlier speakers. Senator Walsh, in leading the debate for the Government, said-if I understood him correctly-that there is only one issue on which the Government has not yet stated a firm policy in respect of its overall economic policies; that is, discounting the consumer price index for devaluation. That is a very interesting statement. I ask Senator Walsh and the Government-perhaps Senator Cook, who will follow me in this debate, will help me out-because I would be very interested to know, and I am sure the people of Australia would be interested to know, precisely what is the Government's policy on monetary targets, interest rates, wages, the export sector of this economy, with the reduction that is taking place in export incentives, taxation and the encouragement of investment. Many people in Australia are asking questions about these matters. Senator Walsh not only side-stepped those matters but he also did not address any of the very telling criticisms made by Senator Rae and Senator Messner.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last 10 weeks alone, since 1 February, the Australian dollar has fallen in value by a record amount to a record low. Against the United States dollar it has fallen by 17.8 per cent. Against sterling it has fallen by a massive 26.5 per cent. Against the yen it has fallen by 20 per cent. Against the deutschemark it has fallen by 21.2 per cent. Against the average of the currencies of our major trading partners the Australian dollar has fallen in value by 19.2 per cent. These are figures to cause all Australians great concern. It is no wonder that the value of the dollar has, for the first time in my memory, become a focal point of everyday conversation for most Australians. The fall in the value of our currency and, therefore, our real standard of living-let us not forget that-is symptomatic of serious problems facing Australia. Those problems are not just economic although economic factors play a major part. We are heading for a record deficit in our balance of payments on current account in 1984-85-probably a figure of $10,500m to $11,000m. That is $2,000m more than the Government forecast at the time of the last Budget. Our overseas debt is skyrocketing and with it the interest on that debt. The interest bill on our foreign debt has increased by 200 per cent since 1980 and most of that increase has occurred in the last two years. There is the answer to Senator Maguire's point, with which I agree, in terms of the importance and the significance of the invisibles deficit in the balance of payments. It is coming very largely from skyrocketing and continuing interest bill increases.

Our interest bill on our foreign debt now represents 12 per cent of total exports. That means that we need $1 of every $8 worth of exports simply to meet the interest bill on our foreign debt. That takes no account at all of the need eventually to repay the debt itself. No wonder the Australian Finance Conference, in a submission to the Economic Planning Advisory Council in recent days, said that our overseas debt is now threatening Australia's long term growth prospects.

Our economic growth rate is declining. Gone are the heady days of 1984 when the Government basked in the wake and the wash of the recovery of the United States economy, the breaking of the drought in 1983 and the previous Government's wages pause. The decline in our inflation rate has plateaued and the rate is showing signs of increasing, despite the fact that it is still higher than those of most of the other major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and despite the fact that we still have the devaluation impact of the recent exchange rate decline to take into account. That will probably add directly about 2 per cent to the CPI. Unemployment is on the rise again. Money supply is increasing at an unhealthily rapid rate and, despite this increase in the money supply, interest rates are rising in complete contradiction of the claims of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that they would fall. As Senator Rae and Senator Messner so rightly pointed out, interest rates are rising directly as a result of the actions of this Government. We are being taxed at a record level and government charges are having an increasingly severe impact on all sectors of industry. No wonder the economy is showing signs of sluggishness again. No wonder unemployment is on the rise again. These are some of the economic reasons lying behind the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. They cannot be ignored. There are also significant political reasons, all of which add up to a Prime Minister and a government which have lost control, a government which has lost the capacity to govern.

Let us look at the Government's record since the last election. It is an appalling record of vacillation, dithering, confusion and lack of leadership. First there was the MX missile fiasco, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) backed away from previously given support to our major ally, the United States, under pressure from the left wing of the Labor Party-a 180-degree turnaround-all done on the basis of a few hasty phone calls across the world without any serious consideration by the Cabinet. This fiasco was closely followed by the ill-fated visit of the Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden) to Kampuchea and Thailand during which time he managed to put off side entirely all our friends in the Association of South East Asian Nations. Then there was the abandonment of monetary targets by the Treasurer. Then the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) got himself and the Government into all sorts of trouble over the iniquitous effects of the assets test on many pensioners and particularly pensioners on farms. Mixed up with all this has been the Government's somersault on the police tapes in New South Wales, its continuing and increasing confusion on the issue of restructuring the taxation system, the defeat of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance (Mr Walsh) over the reintroduction of tertiary fees and the most recent debacle, the confusion generated by the Prime Minister last week throughout both the union movement and the business community with his statement about the productivity case. This litany of mismanagement, inconsistency and bungling by the Prime Minister and the Government has reached alarming proportions. It is a major factor in the decline of the Australian dollar and therefore in our living standards because, quite simply, the rest of the world has lost confidence in the ability of the Australian Government to govern-and very understandably so.

The implications of the dramatic fall in the value of the dollar are profound. I agree with Senator Maguire that certainly there are some sectors of the economy which will benefit in the short run, in particular the export-oriented rural and mining industries. Australian producers of goods which receive competition from imports will also benefit in the short term. But these benefits to some sectors of the economy are achieved at great cost to the economy as a whole because, in its simplest terms, depreciation of our currency means that we have to sell more and more abroad in order to pay for the same amount of imports. This automatically means a reduction in the living standards, in the real income, of every Australian, unless we can capitalise on the short term increased competitiveness which devaluation provides.

The only way we can capitalise on this situation is for the Government to take firm and responsible economic management decisions in the light of the reduced capacity of the economy to pay. This involves some tough decisions. It requires the Government to exercise much tighter restraint on its expenditure. Government expenditure has ballooned wildly in each of the last two Budgets. It must be reined in, and even more extensively so as a result of the depreciation of the currency. It requires the Government to reduce its Budget deficit so that it puts less pressure on money markets. It requires the Government to reintroduce firm targets for monetary growth rates and to communicate these to the market; a market which at the moment is very confused as to where this Government is going. It requires the Government to exercise the maximum influence over the trade union movement and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to have wage increases discounted for the effects of devaluation. To say that that is a decision to be taken several months down the road is a nonsense because the longer the Government delays taking a decision on that issue the greater the lack of confidence and the greater the uncertainty that will be created in the community. It also requires the Government to use its influence to have abandoned the productivity case scheduled for later this year. It requires the Government to press ahead with freeing up those sectors of our economy where there are rigidities which prevent us from producing efficiently at effective costs. It is quite essential that the Government tackle head on the need for greater flexibility in our wage fixing system and the vexed question of the ever escalating labour on-costs that are plaguing industry generally.

If we can achieve these things we can capitalise on the opportunities which the depreciation of the dollar opens up for us, but if we do not we are inevitably headed for further lack of competitiveness, increased inflation, reduced employment and progressively declining living standards. We can either try to get it right ourselves or have the mechanism of the market place impose its disciplines on us. It is essential that the Prime Minister and the Government take a lead in this. It is not too late. As Senator Rae outlined earlier, we have great potential as a nation, but that potential will not last if we continue to fritter away our opportunities under this leaderless and rudderless Government. If it does exercise leadership I can assure the Government that it will receive the support of the Opposition, but the regrettable fact is that leadership is not being given. That is the reason why Senator Rae, on behalf of the Opposition, has submitted this matter of public importance today. The Prime Minister is not only not showing leadership, he is also adding to the confusion and to the declining confidence, both within and outside Australia, by a series of contradictory and vacillating actions that are the opposite of leadership.

The Treasurer also has a great responsibility to exert leadership at this time, but where is the Treasurer? He has become the invisible man of Australian politics in recent weeks. Is it because he is deliberately distancing himself from the Prime Minister; is it because he is incapable of performing his duties now that the going has got tough; or is it because the three Australian Labor governments-the so-called right wing Labor Government, the so-called left of centre Labor Government and the certainly far left Labor Government-have collectively become incapable of governing?

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been out of the country. Don't you read the newspapers?

—If he has been out of the country in recent weeks, he should have been back here because he has a very serious problem. In recent weeks we have seen a formally factionalised government in very serious disarray. At a crucial time in our economic development we have a Prime Minister and a Government tragically lacking any exercise of firm and responsible government. The situation is serious. It urgently demands leadership. The Prime Minister and the Government are failing Australia and Australians by their inability or unwillingness to provide this leadership. The Opposition urges the Government to act now to stop the slide before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in many respects a pity that the Opposition has chosen to bring on this discussion of a matter of public importance today. It is a pity because it tends to conform with the tradition of members of the Opposition to see no avenue for themselves on the economy except to carp, to criticise and in general to develop an image of gloom and doom. They have not been on strong grounds ever in that approach. They are not on strong grounds today. The economy is in firm and resolute hands, being well managed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) with the support of the rest of the Cabinet and the Caucus. Nonetheless, the gloom and doom continue to be generated and sooner or later someone will have to save members of the Opposition. What do they want? Do they want to shake business confidence, undermine the standing of the economy further and, therefore, wear the blame for any difficulties which might arise? (Quorum formed) The point I was making was that the Opposition has done nothing but try to generate gloom and doom about the economy and that, therefore, it must bear some responsibility if it is true, as it claims, that it has a special relationship with the business community and if some businessmen, in part misguided, believe the gloom and doom that it creates. Let it be put clearly on the agenda that if members of the Opposition continue to be carping, critical and doom-mongering they have to bear the responsibility for those sections of the business sector which may well believe them.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the truth is that the economy is in firm and resolute hands and is developing well. That is illustrated no better than by the performance of the Australian stock exchanges trading at record levels. The performance of the stock exchanges could be contrasted with what has been described as the irrational performance of the foreign exchange market. Looking at the irrationality of some of the choices made on the foreign exchange market has encouraged members of the Opposition to bring forward this matter of public importance today. They divine a fall in the Australian dollar, which is of course quite a substantial fall, and seek to exploit that by shaking the confidence of the community through their traditional approach, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in the other place and his discredited deputy, Mr Howard, have been doing, of continuing to attack and undermine the Government.

The reason members of the Opposition have adopted this policy is that they recognise that a strong economy equals a strong government. They know that the economy is performing well. They therefore try to cast a spell over it in order to undermine the Government. We are seeing a debased use of economic statistics and argument for fairly base political purposes, and one ought to recognise that. It was said by my predecessor in argument, Senator Short, that were credit due credit would be given. Senator Short was not here between 1983 and the beginning of this term in 1985. He ought to be informed that had he been here he would have known that, after we had performed the miracle of the economic summit, developed the Economic Planning Advisory Council and established the accord as a firmly adopted instrument of economic regulation, something that the business community and the commentators were all giving us credit for, the Opposition was not moved to give credit where it was due but continued to try to undermine those achievements. So we are seeing nothing but a continuous stream of carping criticism.

Members of the Opposition, by this matter of public importance, have tried to focus on three different areas. First, they have tried to discredit our economic performance, and I want to say something in detail about that shortly. Secondly, they have tried to undermine the accord and the Government's management of wages policy, and I want to go into some detail about that as well. Their third and most recently discovered method of attacking the Government is to pretend that somehow or other the Prime Minister is not in a firm position in his leadership of the Party. I participate in all avenues of the Australian Labor Party and its Caucus and I can say quite clearly that he is and that he has the full backing of the Caucus and of the Party in his economic management and his leadership. Let no one on the other side pretend, as Senator Short did a moment ago in reading a somewhat fanciful litany of so-called failings of the Government, that the Prime Minister is not strongly and powerfully supported by all sectors of the Caucus and that they will not make sure that our economic performance continues. Of course, we will continue in government for a long time-the very thing that the Opposition does not want.
